_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility:         BAYHILL FERTILIZER INC.
  
        Contact:         Bill Harfst

         Manager       Dennis Fullerton

         Phone:           309-537-3188


        1.       Facility  Policy:   The owners, management, and employees of Bayhill Fertilizer are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia by utilization of proper equipment, regular inspection and maintenance and training of all persons tha work with the material. Should an accidental release occur, the facility has orientated the local fire department and the local emergency planning committee so the can plan for resorse to any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

         2.       Facility information:   The primary activity at the facility is storage of fertilizer for sale to farmer. Anyhdrous ammonia ia received, stored, and  distributed for direct application as a NUTRIENT for crop production.  The  maximum quantity stored would be 385,000  pounds in the storages and nurse tanks.

          3.       Worse-case Scenario and Alternate Release Scenario:   The worse case release scenario would be the release of the total content of one of the storage tank release as a gas over 10 minunite. The maximum quantity release would be 119,000   pounds, which represents the volume of one of the storage tank at 85 persent capacity as limited by design standard and company procedures. The distance to the endpoint of dispersion based on the model used is .1.09 miles.

                      The alternative case release scenario is assumed to be release from a rupure of a 1 inch transfer hose, with 2900 pounds realease over 2 minutes. The distance to the endpoint of dispersion is .31 miles

            4.        The accidental release program:    The facility complies with the Rules and Regulations related to the handling of Anhydrous Ammonia and Low Pressure Nitrogen Solution, Containers and Storage Facilities. These regulatio

ns administered by the Illinois Department of Agriculyure are conistent with  OHSA 29 CFR 1910.111 regarding storage and handling anhydrous ammonia.

             5.         The Five-year Accident History.       There hase been  NO  accendental release of anhydrous ammonia for the last  five years that has caused deaths, injuries, evacuation, sheltering in place, propery damage or environmental damage. None to our knowledge.

              6.        The Emergency Responce Program:     The facility has a written emergency action plan in accordance with OHSA standard 29 CFR 1910.38.  Provide state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III of EPCRA. Our  emergency response action plan has been review with the local fire department and coordination inthe community response planning.  
                      If a large release of anhydrous take place at the facility , the required respones action is to evacuate the area of spill and call 911 and applicable emergency response number.
                        1.Within 15 minutes of detemining the amount of the release would be over 100 pounds, the Emergency Coordinator will be notify
                             The National Emergency Response Center @ 800-424-8802
                        2. With-in 1 hour of determining the amount of release would effect the environment, the Emergency Coordinator will notify:
                                The Illinois Environmental Management Agency @ 800-782-7860 in state or 217-782-7820 out of state

                 7.  Planned Changes to improve safety:     Safety inprovement is an on going process at the facility. Periodic evaluation are performed to assess the conditions OF THE FACILITY. There are no additionalspecific safety recommendations regarding storage or use of anhydrous ammonia for implementation at this time.
